statements.text: Theseus, son of King Aegeus of Athens, is famed for his strength and daring among the youth of the city.
King Minos of Crete forces Athens to send regular tributes of youths to his island as punishment for earlier offenses.
Theseus volunteers to join one such tribute, assuring Aegeus that he will return alive from Crete.
Daedalus designs the Labyrinth so cunningly that once inside, even the Minotaur cannot find a way out.
The Minotaur, half man and half bull, prowls the corridors of the Labyrinth and devours those sent as tribute.
Ariadne is moved to pity for one of the foreign youths chosen for the Labyrinth and secretly resolves to help him survive.
Ariadne gives Theseus a ball of thread so that he can mark his path through the Labyrinth and find the entrance again.
Deep within the Labyrinth, Theseus meets the Minotaur in combat and kills the monster with his sword.
Following the unwound thread, Theseus retraces his steps and brings the surviving youths safely out of the Labyrinth.
Theseus secretly sails away from Crete with Ariadne, taking her from her father’s island under cover of night.
On the island of Naxos, Ariadne is left behind in one well-known version of the tale, and Dionysus later claims her as his bride.
As Theseus’s ship approaches Athens, Aegeus looks for the promised white sail that would signal his son’s survival.
Seeing only a dark sail, Aegeus throws himself into the water in despair, and later Greeks say the sea there bears his name.
After news spreads that Theseus has slain the Minotaur, the people of Athens remember him as the hero who freed them from Crete’s tribute.
In stories told on Crete, Minos remains a powerful king whose anger once made Athens fear the command that sent its youths into the Labyrinth.
Bound to Minos in Crete, Daedalus knows that his knowledge of the Labyrinth and the fall of the Minotaur has made his own position precarious.
